But maybe in another part of the box? Wait, the box is 2 units in height and 2 in width. If we could somehow use the remaining 1 unit in length, but it's not enough for a 3-unit waffle. 

Alternatively, maybe split the waffles into different parts of the box. For example, place one waffle along the length (4 units) but in a different orientation. Wait, but the waffle's 3-unit side can't fit into the 2-unit dimensions. So no.

So, in the 4-unit length, each waffle takes up 3 units. So, how many non-overlapping 3-unit segments can we fit in 4 units? Just one. Because 3 + 3 = 6, which is more than 4. So only one segment of 3 units. Therefore, in each cross-sectional layer (2x2), you can place four waffles, each occupying 3 units of length. But since the length is 4, you can't have more than one segment of 3 units. Therefore, each cross-sectional layer can have four waffles arranged along the length. But the cross-sectional layer is 2x2, and each waffle is 1x1x3. So placing four waffles in the cross-section (each in a 1x1 position) along the length. 

But that would mean that the four waffles are all placed along the same 3-unit length. But the box is 4 units long, so there's 1 unit of empty space. But since the waffles can't be split, that's the maximum. 

Therefore, the total number of waffles that can fit is 4. So if the user has seven, they need to eat 7 - 4 = 3. So the answer is C. 

But wait, maybe there's a way to arrange them in a different orientation? Let me think again. Suppose instead of placing all waffles along the length, maybe some are placed vertically. Wait, but the vertical dimensions are 2 units. The waffle is 3 units in one dimension. So that's impossible. So no. 

Alternatively, maybe combine different orientations? Like some along the length and some along the width or height. But the width and height are 2 units, so the 3-unit side can't fit there. 

Hmm. So I think the maximum number is 4. So the answer is C. 3.
